title: Equipment Cleaning
description: Requirements for equipment cleaning and sanitation including documented procedures, cleaning schedules, sanitation verification, water quality for cleaning, and cleaning chemical management

requirements.text: Are food contact equipment surfaces clean?
mandatoryStatements: All food contact equipment surfaces must be maintained in clean and sanitary condition
Surfaces must be free from product residues, soil, biofilm, and visible contamination
Cleaning procedures must be documented and followed
Cleaning effectiveness must be verified
Immediate cleaning required if contamination observed
requirements.verificationExpectations: Daily visual inspection of food contact surface cleanliness, weekly ATP testing or environmental swabbing
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Pre-operational inspections before each production run, continuous monitoring during production

requirements.text: Are non-food contact equipment surfaces clean?
mandatoryStatements: Non-food contact equipment surfaces must be kept clean
Cleaning prevents pest harborage and pathogen reservoirs
Regular cleaning schedules must include non-food contact surfaces
Soil accumulation must be prevented
Cleaning verification must be documented
requirements.verificationExpectations: Weekly inspection of non-food contact surface cleanliness, monthly deep cleaning verification
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Daily visual monitoring, immediate cleaning if excessive soil observed

requirements.text: Are items (totes, bins, etc.) that are used to hold or store product clean?
mandatoryStatements: Totes, bins, and product-holding items must be cleaned and sanitized before use
Items must be maintained in sanitary condition between uses
Cleaning and sanitizing procedures must be established
Pre-use inspection must verify cleanliness
Dirty containers must be removed from service immediately
requirements.verificationExpectations: Daily inspection of container cleanliness before use, weekly cleaning procedure verification
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Visual inspection of each container before product contact, immediate rejection of unclean containers

requirements.text: During cleaning, are food products and packaging materials protected from contamination?
mandatoryStatements: Food products and packaging must be protected during cleaning operations
Products must be covered, removed, or physically separated during cleaning
Cleaning chemicals and water spray must not contact products
Cleaning schedule should minimize overlap with production when possible
Personnel must be trained on product protection requirements during cleaning
requirements.verificationExpectations: Weekly observation of cleaning operations for product protection compliance, monthly training verification
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Supervisory oversight during all cleaning operations, immediate halt if product exposure occurs

requirements.text: Are cooling units, including coils in coolers and freezers, clean and free of aged, dirty ice?
mandatoryStatements: Cooling unit coils must be maintained clean and free from dust and buildup
Ice accumulation must be managed through regular defrosting
Condensate drip pans must be clean and draining properly
Preventive maintenance schedule must include coil cleaning
Dirty ice must be removed and units cleaned
requirements.verificationExpectations: Monthly cooling coil inspection and cleaning as needed, quarterly preventive maintenance verification
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Weekly visual inspection of coil condition, immediate cleaning if excessive buildup observed

requirements.text: Where fans or other air circulation equipment are used, are they maintained and operated in a manner that minimizes the potential for contaminating product, equipment, and packaging materials?
mandatoryStatements: Fans and air circulation equipment must be cleaned regularly
Airflow must be directed from clean to less-clean areas
Fans must not blow across contaminated areas toward product zones
Filter replacement schedules must be maintained
Fan positioning must prevent shedding of debris onto products
requirements.verificationExpectations: Monthly fan cleaning verification, quarterly airflow pattern assessment
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Weekly visual inspection of fan cleanliness, immediate cleaning if contamination risk identified

requirements.text: Is stored equipment that is not used on a daily basis stored in a clean condition with food-contact surfaces protected and/or are they retained on cleaning schedules in some manner, even though they are not in use?
mandatoryStatements: Infrequently used equipment must be cleaned before storage
Food contact surfaces must be protected from dust and contamination during storage
Periodic cleaning must occur even during storage periods (monthly minimum)
Equipment must be cleaned and verified before return to service
Storage procedures must be documented
requirements.verificationExpectations: Quarterly inspection of stored equipment condition, annual review of storage cleaning schedules
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Monthly cleaning of stored equipment per schedule, pre-use inspection before return to service

requirements.text: Are all utensils, hoses, and other items not being used, stored clean and in a manner to prevent contamination?
mandatoryStatements: Utensils, hoses, and tools must be stored clean in designated areas
Storage must prevent floor contact and contamination exposure
Hoses must be coiled and elevated off floor
Utensils may be stored hung or in sanitizer solutions
Storage orientation must facilitate drainage and drying
requirements.verificationExpectations: Weekly inspection of utensil and tool storage areas for proper organization and cleanliness
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Daily verification of proper storage practices, immediate correction of floor contact or improper storage

requirements.text: Are maintenance tools that are used in the production and storage areas of the facility clean, sanitary and corrosion free?
mandatoryStatements: Maintenance tools used in production areas must be clean, sanitary, and corrosion-free
Tools must be designated for food area use only
Color-coding system should differentiate food area from non-food area tools
Tool storage must be in designated clean areas
Inspection procedures must verify tool condition before use
requirements.verificationExpectations: Monthly tool condition inspection, quarterly verification of tool designation system
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Visual inspection before each use, immediate removal of corroded or dirty tools

requirements.text: Are excess lubricants and grease removed from the equipment and are lubricant catch pans fitted where needed?
mandatoryStatements: Excess lubricants and grease must be removed from equipment surfaces
Catch pans must be installed under lubrication points
Food-grade lubricants must be used in product zones
Catch pans must be emptied regularly
Lubrication procedures must prevent over-application
requirements.verificationExpectations: Monthly inspection of lubrication points and catch pans, quarterly review of lubrication procedures
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Weekly verification that catch pans are in place and emptied, immediate cleanup of excess lubricant

mandatoryStatements: All food contact equipment surfaces must be maintained in a clean and sanitary condition free from product residues, soil, biofilm, and visible contamination
Non-food contact equipment surfaces must be kept clean to prevent accumulation of soil and harboring of pests that could indirectly contaminate food products or food contact areas
Totes, bins, containers, and other product-holding items must be cleaned and sanitized before use and maintained in sanitary condition between uses

During cleaning operations, all food products and packaging materials must be protected from contamination by cleaning chemicals, water spray, aerosols, and debris through covering, removal, or physical barriers

Cooling unit coils in refrigerators and freezers must be maintained clean and free from ice buildup, dust accumulation, and microbial growth that could contaminate products or reduce cooling efficiency

Fans and air circulation equipment must be cleaned regularly, positioned to avoid blowing across contaminated areas toward product zones, and maintained to prevent shedding of dust, condensation, or debris onto products

Equipment stored for infrequent use must be cleaned before storage, have food contact surfaces protected from dust and contamination, and either cleaned before use or maintained on periodic cleaning schedules even during storage periods

Utensils, hoses, squeegees, and other tools not actively in use must be stored in designated clean areas with proper orientation (hoses coiled and elevated, utensils hung or stored in sanitizer solutions) to prevent contamination and facilitate drainage
Maintenance tools used in production areas must be maintained in clean, sanitary, and corrosion-free condition, designated for food area use only, and stored separately from non-food area tools

Excess lubricants and grease must be removed from equipment surfaces to prevent accumulation, dripping onto products, or harboring contamination; catch pans must be installed under lubrication points and emptied regularly
capaInject: When food contact surfaces are found unclean, immediately cease production, thoroughly clean and sanitize all affected equipment, verify cleaning effectiveness through visual inspection and ATP testing or environmental swabs, identify root cause (inadequate cleaning procedures, insufficient time, lack of training), revise master sanitation schedule, and provide retraining on proper cleaning techniques

If non-food contact surfaces show excessive soil buildup, immediately clean affected areas, expand cleaning schedules to include previously overlooked surfaces, increase cleaning frequency in problem areas, assign specific accountability for non-food contact surface cleaning, and implement regular management verification inspections

For dirty product-holding containers, immediately remove from service, establish centralized cleaning and sanitizing stations with documented procedures, implement pre-use inspection requirements, consider disposable liners for difficult-to-clean containers, and establish container rotation systems ensuring adequate cleaning cycle time

When products or packaging are exposed during cleaning operations, immediately stop cleaning, assess contamination risk to exposed materials, quarantine potentially affected items, establish protocols requiring product removal or protection before cleaning activities, schedule cleaning during non-production periods where possible, and train cleaning personnel on product protection requirements

If cooling unit coils are dirty or ice-laden, immediately defrost and clean units, establish preventive maintenance schedules for coil cleaning, install drip pans to catch condensate, verify adequate drainage systems, monitor for ice buildup that indicates temperature cycling issues, and consider installing coil guards to prevent direct product contact

When fans contaminate products through airflow patterns, immediately assess fan placement and airflow direction, reposition or redirect fans to blow from clean areas toward less-clean areas, install filters on intake fans, increase fan cleaning frequency, establish airflow mapping studies, and consider installation of air curtains or HEPA filtration in critical areas

For stored equipment lacking cleanliness or protection, immediately clean all stored equipment, establish written storage procedures requiring cleaning before storage and protection of food contact surfaces (covers, wrapping, inverted storage), implement periodic cleaning even during storage periods (monthly minimum), label equipment with last cleaning date, and require cleaning verification before return to service

When utensils and tools are improperly stored, immediately relocate to designated storage areas, provide adequate racks, hooks, or containers for proper storage, establish elevation requirements to prevent floor contact, provide sanitizer buckets for short-term utensil storage with documented change frequency, mark tools for food-area-only use, and train personnel on proper storage orientation

If maintenance tools are dirty or corroded, immediately remove from service, clean and sanitize or replace tools, establish color-coding system differentiating food area tools from general maintenance tools, provide dedicated tool storage in production areas, implement tool inspection procedures before use, and consider stainless steel or non-corrosive tool alternatives for food areas

When excess lubricants are observed, immediately clean equipment to remove excess, install or empty catch pans, evaluate lubrication procedures for over-application, specify food-grade lubricants for all equipment in or near product zones, establish lubrication schedules preventing over-application, train maintenance personnel on minimum effective lubrication quantities, and inspect equipment regularly for lubricant migration or accumulation
traceabilityInject: Maintain master sanitation schedules documenting all equipment requiring cleaning with cleaning frequency, methods, chemicals used, responsible personnel, and verification requirements

Keep cleaning logs for all food contact equipment showing date cleaned, time, person performing cleaning, chemicals used, contact times, and verification signatures from supervisor or quality assurance

Document cleaning validation and verification records including ATP test results, environmental monitoring swabs for Listeria or other pathogens, visual inspection findings, and corrective actions for failures

Retain cleaning chemical usage logs showing chemical concentration, preparation date, test strip verification of concentration, and disposal dates for mixed solutions ensuring proper strength and freshness

Maintain equipment storage logs for infrequently used equipment documenting cleaning date before storage, protection methods applied, periodic cleaning during storage, and pre-use cleaning before return to service

Keep preventive maintenance schedules for cooling units, fans, and air circulation equipment showing maintenance frequency, activities performed (coil cleaning, filter replacement, fan cleaning), and findings of dirt, ice, or other contamination concerns
Document tool and utensil storage audits showing inspection dates, findings of improper storage, contamination of stored items, corrective actions taken, and verification of proper storage practices

Retain maintenance tool cleaning and designation records showing tool identification, food-area vs. non-food-area designation, cleaning procedures, inspection findings, and replacement dates for corroded or damaged tools
micro_inject: Biofilm formation on inadequately cleaned food contact surfaces provides protected environments where Listeria monocytogenes, Salmonella, and other pathogens can persist for extended periods and continuously contaminate products despite routine cleaning attempts

Dirty non-food contact surfaces serve as harborage for pests and reservoirs for environmental pathogens; dust and soil accumulation provides nutrients supporting bacterial growth and harbors Listeria species that can transfer to food contact areas through aerosols or worker contact

Product residues remaining in containers between uses provide nutrients for rapid bacterial growth; a single contaminated container can introduce millions of pathogenic bacteria into fresh product batches creating widespread contamination

Cleaning chemical spray and aerosols during active production can settle on food products introducing toxic chemical residues; additionally, aerosols from cleaning dirty equipment can distribute bacteria throughout the production environment contaminating previously clean areas

Dirty cooling coils and condensate accumulation create high-moisture environments ideal for Listeria monocytogenes growth; condensate dripping from contaminated coils directly onto products below is a common source of Listeria contamination in refrigerated foods

Fans blowing across dirty surfaces, trash areas, or floor drains toward product zones create aerosol transmission pathways for pathogens; Listeria and Salmonella can be distributed throughout facilities via air currents from contaminated sites to food contact surfaces

Equipment stored dirty or unprotected accumulates environmental contamination including dust, pest debris, and opportunistic pathogens; when returned to service, this contaminated equipment introduces stored pathogens directly into production lines

Improperly stored utensils contacting floors or contaminated surfaces become vectors for pathogen transfer; floor contact exposes tools to the highest bacterial loads in facilities including Listeria environmental strains that then transfer to products during use

Corroded maintenance tools shed rust particles into production areas while corrosion pits harbor bacteria that cannot be removed through cleaning; these tools introduce both physical and microbiological contamination each time they contact equipment or surfaces

Excess lubricants attract dust and dirt forming a paste-like substance that harbors bacteria in sheltered environments; lubricant drips onto products create consumer complaints and food safety concerns while providing growth medium for lipophilic bacterial species
